Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: In Physics 180 you learn the basis of mechanics all the way up to waves and the Doppler effect. A great introductory physics course.
It was my first physics course so I developed an understanding of all types of ideas and problem solving.
This course definitely rejuvenated my calculus skills (by necessity, not design), and gave me a newfound appreciation for physics.

From this course I have not only gained knowledge about Physics, but I think I have developed a more perseverant attitude for doing my work, having been challenged by the problem sets. I have also made better habit of taking good notes and reviewing old notes after class.
Physics, physics, physics. There are so many different topics covered in this class. Kinematics, gravity, friction, orbitals, conservation of energy, oscillations and more.
physics

Wow. I walked into this class knowing very little about Physics and feeling super intimidated by the class, but it ended up being one of my favorite classes. Physics is a beautiful subject and its taught really well here. I developed great problem-solving and math skills.
Everything you'd expect out of a more advanced version of AP Physics C: Mechanics.

You learn the basics of any physics I class. However, the problem sets were all very detailed and advanced questions that were hard and at a very high level which was annoying for those who did not wish to advance past intro physics. It was too much information that was not needed for a beginner class.
You learn a lot of quantitative analysis, and how the world works scientifically. Steep learning curve, and a very difficult class, but a rewarding one nonetheless.
Physics. But also how to collaborate with my peers on problems.
I learned some problem solving skills and got to brush up on my physics knowledge. I really enjoyed this course!
Good understanding of basic physics.
This was my first physics class so I learned a lot! You can see the syllabus re: what you learn, in general, it is a different way of thinking about the world.
Standard University Physics experience. A lot of work, but it helps you understand the concepts gone over in class.

This course reinforced my knowledge of physical concepts and helped me develop problem-solving skills to synthesize information from different areas. While some introductory calculus skills were used (basic differentiation and integration), the mathematical exercises that were required emphasized finding the relationships between physical quantities rather than complicated calculus analyses.

I learned a lot about physics and its applications from climbing up Science Hill to class to the orbits of celestial bodies. I also became more passionate about the subject which made me more certain of what I want to follow as a major.
I'd had (sparse) physics before, but this class solidified my knowledge of kinematics, torque, etc., and physical mechanics in general.
Basic high-school-AP-level physics, straightforward material (or at least as straightforward as physics can ever be).
A standard introductory class into physics: mechanics, gravity, and energy conservation. The class assumes a general calculus background, but the math never goes too incredible.
I learned a lot more about concepts in physics I had previously been exposed to in high school.

I learned how to think about physics rationally, which was not a skill I had in high school in the subject of physics. Professor Steinacker was especially great at showing students patterns in the concepts we were learning.
I learned important physics topics in depth and leaned to appreciate the beauty and conciseness of how few physics laws can be applied to solve a variety of problems.
Kinematics, forces, energy, momentum, relative motion, COM, inertia, rotational kinematics, rotational energy, angular momentum, torque, gravitation, transverse waves, simple harmonic motion
Well some physics of course! Pretty straightforward what this class teaches and Id say I learned it so that is good right?

I developed my knowledge of modeling kinematics, energy, and rotational dynamics through algebraic and calculus-based equations.

More broadly, I gained first-hand experience with physics-based approaches to problem solving. (I.e. listing the known factors and outlining their relationships, then logically rearranging things until what's unknown is uncovered)
This course improved my problem solving skills
I learned how to manage having a LOT of homework every week!
I learned how to approach problems with tact; even when I don't know the answer, just thinking about the different components/angles to approach the problem is a useful skill.

I learned a general way to think about and approach physics problems. The collaborative aspect of the course taught me how to work in this sort of environment. I also learned more specific knowledge about mechanics.

In this class, I learned the foundations of classical physics, from kinematics to waves, etc. In general, I learned  how to analyze physics word problems to discern what the problem was asking and how to solve it.
I learned physics

After taking physics 180, I have gained an in-depth understanding of mechanical physics taught using integral calculus. Topics ranging from forces to energy and harmonic motion are all addressed at great length in the class.

I gained a very thorough understanding of basic mechanical physics concepts, and truly understood some tough concepts such as gravity and simple harmonic motion in ways that I did not previously comprehend from my high school physics.
This course is a very thorough introduction to the field of physics, and there's pretty much something for everyone: kinematics, planetary motion, rotational kinetics, waves.
I refreshed my knowledge of AP Physics C (Mechanics) and applied it to more outwardly complex problems.

Having come into the course with no physics background, the knowledge, skills, and insights I gained were quite remarkable. I feel like I have an in-depth understanding of physics now and i think that this course was absolutely excellent in terms of teaching.
mechanics

I expanded my understanding on knowledge that I had acquired during high school. The course offered an interesting point of view on how to derive various formulas that had been considered as just "given" up to this point.
In-depth knowledge on mechanics and how the properties of Physics apply to the real world.
I learned about how to apply basic understanding to tackle more difficult problems and how to apply repeated themes to increasingly difficult concepts.
Basic physics-- kinematics, gravity, forces, etc.
How to apply general physics ideas to multi-part problems
I learned how to think critically and developed my problem solving sjills. I learned to reason through a problem and work out many aspects from just several details making physics seem beautiful.
This class taught me how to think and how to study.
I learned a lot about physics and also a ton of the math behind it. As my first serious physics class, I learned about kinematic, rotational motion, center of mass, gravity, and waves.
Knowledge of introductory physics.

You cover many of the expected topics in a first semester introductory physics course, with in-depth examples and in-depth PSETS. Kinematics, forces, momentum, torque, energy, oscillations, waves...etc.
Detailed knowledge of the fundamentals of mechanics in Physics, as well as knowledge about how to effectively approach Physics problems. Also great practice using Calculus.
Introductory physics including forces, energy, rotational kinematics, simple harmonic motion and waves.
I improved my ability to think quantitatively quickly
Got better at algebra, grasped new physical concepts.

I learned so much about how things work around me. I am constantly asking my self questions of why things happen that I see everyday, and that is one reason why I loved chemistry because I could explain things around me. This is precisely what I learned in physics.
I gained a basic understanding of physics.
I learned how to incorporate calculus into physics.
Critical thinking skills
A good overview of Physics concepts to move forward with.
I extended my physics knowledge and learned how to work hard on problem sets.
A thorough overview of basic physics concepts, with some things like harmonic motion and the wave equation thrown in by an enthusiastic professor.
I learned basic physics.

This course is a good introduction to college-level physics. That being said, if you didn't take AP Physics in high school, or haven't looked at the material in a while, it's probably going to dominate your schedule.

Having taken AP Physics C in high school, most of the material in this class was familiar. This class is much more rigorous with the math involved, and it was the first time I had ever used a Taylor series in a physics class.

I learned the basics of kinematics, forces, energy, rotational motion, waves and harmonic oscillators. I also developed a strong intuition for visualizing motion. And I learned how to set up a problem and break it down into steps in a very systematic and reliable way. Most of all I learned that physics can be elegant and rewarding, instead of frustrating and hard, which is how I felt coming in to it from high school.
I learned more about the basic applications and uses of physics as well as how to manipulate physics variables and formulas in depth.

Learned over the semester not only the knowledge required to approach mechanics problems but also greater confidence, creativity, flexibility and overall capability to work out complex problems with unobvious solutions. I definitely also grew in collaboration skills as I worked through problems with other students who I did not know.
Overall a very strong course. No real weaknesses.
It had really helpful lectures and the PSETS were relevant for the exams. The best part was the availability of the professor for extra help. it was truly amazing.
The course is well-structured and well-taught. The material is difficult but Professor Steinacker does well to help and support you through the course.

Adrianne Steinacker is the absolute best and she is 100% the strength of this course. The weaknesses of this course are the depth of the material one is expected to know in a basic pre-req class that many STEM majors must take

This class is designed to promote student learning and success, IF you have a lot of extra time to spend on it. Without attending office hours (which added an extra 6 to 10 hours to my classes), extensive work outside of class, etc. I'm not sure that passing this course is even possible. However, the instructor is fair and cares deeply about her students, and want to help students who put the effort in.

Strengths: 
Great organization, great professor, great online lecture notes, problems sets are just challenging enough but not too overwhelming 

Weaknesses: 
Discrepancies in grading between TFs seemed unfair

The support in this class is incredible. The professor is absolutely amazing. She has office hours almost every day and works hard to help everyone out while also getting to know all her students by name. There's also a lot of support from the peer tutors which really eased the pressure of the course/workload.

This course is very fast for students who have not taken mush calculus or physics before.  I never took physics in high school and found the material and exams very difficult.  I also only took MATH 116 before this course and found the math hard to follow sometimes.
Very time consuming, but I guess that's the only way to learn physics
You will definitely work a ton more in this class than in any other class, but its totally worth it.

Strengths: Professor Steinacker is great! She is a really entertaining lecturer, and she cares for every one of her students. Even though the topics can be difficult at times, she is very willing to help each student understand the material.
Weaknesses: None really.

The strength was the collaborative attitude was all the students helping each other to solve the problems and the ability to use test corrections on tests. However, the weakness is that the problem set questions are very hard and there is a disconnect between lecture topics and problems on the pset because the pset is much more advanced than the basics learned in class, so the pset takes a very long time to complete each week.
The problem sets are really difficult. But that said, they are worth 35% of your grade, so Steinacker makes them worth your while.
Great course with many resources to utilize for optimal learning. The feedback on homework and exams although generous for grading was not clear on how to answer the problem and learn the material.

I think the course was very well organized. The amount of help you can get outside of the classroom is overwhelming. It is impossible not to do well in the class, if you are committed to learning. The problem sets sometimes were too long, but it may be a subjective opinion because I had a heavy course load this semester.

This class is so demanding, and I think that is both its strength and weakness. You have to dedicate so many hours to office hours and study hall just to get through the psets each week, but if you are willing to make that time investment, you come out knowing so much.

Adriane will post lecture notes for all of her classes after the lecture. So, you can go back and review the material she covered in there. I didn't realize this until a few weeks in but Adriane's lecture notes are WAY more useful than the textbook, so it's worth it it to just use that. They will also go into concepts/ideas slightly more in depth/have a more throughout explanation than in class - so it's always a good idea to check them out. Also, a strength is that there are corrections after each of the 2 midterms, so you can gain back half of the points you lost.

I really like that this course is graded in such a way that most people do very well. The class is taught well and everyone who takes the course seriously will learn something, no matter their physics background. Not the most difficult course but I would prefer if the PSETs focused less on smart algebraic thinking and more on physics

It's Physics 1 -- it can't really be dressed up. But Dr. Steinacker does a great job of making the subject interesting -- she's obviously incredibly intelligent and passionate about physics (especially her background in astrophysics research) and she makes students excited about it too (at least for me!). This was one class where I felt like the professor really made an effort to show students interesting applications of the material so that you felt what you were doing was important and relevant, which is so often lacking in intro STEM classes. The structure of afternoon office hours and evening study halls for psets was also very helpful and it's great that there are so many different times available so that anyone can fit at least one of these sessions into their schedules.

The course is really good Professor Steinacker does a really great job of publishing clear notes and that are well organized and fit well with the problem sets etc. I always felt like I needed to do the psets with other people because they were difficult and some problems were so hard you just need hints, but I really enjoyed working with other people and I think it was a good learning experience. There was a decent amount of algebra.
The study halls every night were the best part.

This course fosters (and for many, demands) a collaborative environment that emphasizes group-based learning. Between Professor Steinacker's well-attended office hours and evening study halls on Hillhouse offer plenty of opportunity for students to work together on problem sets and work to understand the material better. It's important, because the lectures are paced very quickly, so the structure of having an assignment due each week and working on it with other people helps to keep students responsible for the material without falling behind. The problem sets are designed to help students learn the most important concepts. An additional section of 180 might be an improvement on the course to prevent overcrowding, especially because Professor Steinacker tries to encourage greater participation in class and with a full lecture hall, it is difficult to accomplish that engagement.

I personally think the strength of the class are the lectures which are very good and the sense of community that develops around the classroom. The main weakness that I find are the p-sets which are very time consuming and difficult to do.

The class is incredibly well-taught under Prof. Steinacker, though it is certainly challenging. It is highly collaborative and relatively low-stress in terms of grading, but it is also very high in workload.
Less proofs and more problems.
Honestly, too many psets that take too much time. But lecture helps, and Steinacker is the best.

Professor Steinacker makes Physics 180 worth it! The p-sets are really challenging and usually take me at least half a week's worth of work to finish, but as long as you put in the effort to go to office hours and ask questions, you can figure out the right answers to everything. Professor Steinacker and her peer tutors are there to help, and they want you to do well on these p-sets. The two midterms were hard for me in terms of time management - the questions aren't unreasonable in terms of content (you can prepare well by doing the provided practice midterm/going to Professor Steinacker's review session), but you do have to work efficiently, which isn't always easy when you run into a problem you need to take some time to process. The final exam was killer, though. It wasn't so much cumulative as it was focused on the last third of material we covered in class, but the questions were much harder than the midterm content! Professor Steinacker's reviews were helpful, but they didn't really prepare me for the level of difficulty of the exam.

This class pushes you to learn a lot of physics and tackle really difficult problems. It trains you to think like a physicist and to think about how all topics are related in physics and in science. The class homework takes a long time and can be difficult to do independently, but there are so many resources for you to learn and get help: study halls, office hours, peer tutors, etc.

Professor Steinacker herself is certainly the main strength of this course. She is one of the most enthusiastic professors I have ever had the fortune to have as an instructor; she truly cares about the students and wants to make sure they succeed in learning the physics concepts. She is always available to help students and always willing to put more time in. Her tireless energy truly made the class a wonderful experience, despite the abstract-ness of some of the topics.

I also thought that the homework load was very fair. I know that in past years, all ten homework problems were required, but this course was extremely fair in only having students complete 7-8 questions. I would not have minded if all of them were graded, though, rather than only 5 questions graded per pset.

Strengths: well organized, well taught, many resources for help (extensive office hours and study hall), amazing professor, fair exams, test corrections

Weaknesses: some pset problems were too difficult and I found to save time students would just ask for solutions rather than trying to spend more time and effort than necessary to understand how to solve the problem

One strength of this class is how much emphasis there is on collaboration, especially with the psets. I really appreciated that Professor Steinacker encouraged us all to work with and learn from each other. One weakness of the class was that I thought the lectures were a bit disorganized at times. While the lecture notes were always really clear and explained the concepts well, I thought that the lectures focused a bit too much on the math behind the physics rather than the physics concepts themselves.

Considering the material Prof. Steinacker made it super interesting, so Id say shes a solid strength of this course. I think its pretty well set up, in class demonstrations are one of the best parts, grading is exceedingly fair, and overall a good experience. The lecture notes are awesome.

This course can teach students (those who have the time to REALLY dig into it) quite a LOT.

And as time consuming as the problem-sets are, I believe that they teach valuable approaches to general problem solving. I would assert that the problem sets are also good for developing skills around teamwork, as it doesn't seem to be often that they're solved, totally correctly, by a single individual who's working alone.

However, it also seems to me that students can neglect to learn how to actually study physics (building understandings of concepts, learning how to derive & apply formulas, etc.) & simply focus on turning in P-sets. Copying them IS totally possible, and, sadly, does happen.

Of course, copying P-sets is also reflected in exam performance.

My only definite complaint would be that more accurate practice tests and finals should be available, as the practice final that was provided was far more difficult than the actual final.

Also, I know that this would be difficult to provide for a lecture of this size, but a larger emphasis on solving physics problems in general (i.e. more feedback on the format & reasoning students provide to back up their answers) would be nice. Teaching HOW to do physics, and not just providing knowledge of kinematics, dynamics, etc., is, I believe, important.

Physics 180 provides the students with an ample amount of resources in order to help with problem sets as well as any questions one may have about the material. Not only do they have Office hours several times a week but then there are also study halls which I found incredibly helpful if you are struggling with a problem set. As for the weaknesses, I think it would be better to have a consistency in who grades the problem sets because what I have found is that some TA's grade easier than others causing certain people's grades to suffer slightly more than others.

This course, through Psets, gives one a creative approach to problem solving but there are alwaysbquestions in Psets that need complex mathematical manipulations one would never figure out on their own

I found the homework to not be all the helpful for learning the material. Most of the homework was too hard to complete by-myself, so I went to study hall nearly every night. At study hall, someone who did understand the material very well would then answer all my questions, but I couldn't have figured it out on my own. On the contrary, being able to do test corrections was a bug help! Having to go back through my mistakes helped me to understand what I had done correctly and what I had messed up on!

I feel like there isn't enough preparation for the level of difficulty for the types of questions we see on the psets/exams in comparison to what we do in class. Part of this is definitely due to the large amount of material that we try to cover but there should at least be one or two questions in a class that are of the higher caliber/ incorporate multiple concepts at once to prepare for higher-level thinking.
The structure of the course, with lectures, study halls, and office hours, was very helpful. The PSETs prepared us well for the exams and the exams were fair.

Strengths: Professor Steinacker clearly cares about seeing students succeed, and her lectures are very engaging. The midterm exams are challenging, but fair, especially based on the problem sets and exam reviews provided. There is so much help available -- between office hours and study halls. 

Weaknesses: The problem sets are meant to be collaborative, which has its benefits, but there are some problems that seemed to only be solvable with very specific knowledge/strategies that one could not get unless they attended office hours or worked with a friend who had attended. 

Although the problem sets are time consuming and complex, they are weighted to reflect that in the grade, and the complexity was good preparation for exams.

honestly, PRAISE prof steinacker; she put in a huge amount of effort and labor and really helped me learn how to work through a problem. assignments were hugely challenging, but you get through them and are better. i assume this amount of difficulty is necessary for other students, as a pre-med it was a little much...but i did really learn the fundamental concepts as well as a large amount of algebra....

This class was structured very well, and the lecture materials were very accessible and comprehensive. The immense amount of office hours and study halls made asking for help much easier, and as a result the course felt very manageable. Overall, the course was set up very well and I would not change anything.

The Psets are quite difficult but timely completion and thorough work through ensures that the material is mastered. The class is definitely quite Math heavy which may pose a special challenge for some students.

This course is taught very very well, and it is clear that the instructor is both very passionate and very knowledgeable about the course, which allows the students to be more engaged. Also, the opportunities to improve your grades are generous, and the class is structured in a way that allows to students to truly want to learn the content and feel comfortable taking an approach this isn't all about getting the best graded but rather ensuring that the student is really learning.

The class design does a great job keeping you on your toes and keeping you up to date on the material. Weekly problem sets took a long time, but they were worth it, since they helped me cement and reapply the things we'd learned in class that week. 
But my favorite was the time I spent in class. Professor Steinacker is such a fun person to learn from! She showed us funny videos, told jokes, and applied all the principles in interesting ways.

While enthusiastic, Prof. Steinacker sometimes spent much too long in lecture discussing the mathematical basis behind a physics concept. This would be fine in a higher-level class where we were actually using that math, but for this class it just encouraged me to tune out for a while. One strength is the vast student support network: peer tutors, office hours, study halls, you name it. Going to office hours is an excellent way to learn what you need and ace the pset.

A strength of this course was that Professor Steinacker was the best professor I've ever had. She has an in-depth, expansive knowledge of this field, which she explained to us in a way that was easy to understand. She was always available to help us and the amount of time she dedicated to us was quite remarkable. A weakness of this course were the teaching assistants because they really didn't seem engaged and weren't helpful during study halls because they wouldn't check the answer key before launching into an explanation that was either incorrect or beyond the scope of the class.
The teaching by the professor was excellent. However, more TAs could be added during office hours in order to compensate for the increased demand.
The course is large and the material is often dense so it takes some time to understand after class ;however Professor Steinacker is always available and helpful.
Prof Steinacker is truly phenomenal. I was not planning to take 181 but can't imagine leaving her. She pours herself into this class.

The lectures are well organized and interactive. The p-sets are difficult but the study halls and Professor Steinacker's office hours are a tremendous help. There is a very collaborative aspect to doing the p-sets that really facilitates learning.

The strengths are that the lectures are great and the pset do a great job of reinforcing material one should know for exams. The weaknesses are that it can take a lot of time and sometimes important material is covered too close to exams.

The problem sets were very useful for understanding the course material, but almost impossible to do alone.  I would have liked the lecture notes to be posted before each class rather than after so we can follow along during class.
No weaknesses.

Strengths = Prof. Steinacker!!! She's is the most dedicated professor you will ever find.
Weaknesses = a fair amount of work (Pset each week), but can be completed in 3-5 hours if you go to office hours and study hall and work with others on it

The main strength of this course is Professor Steinacker. She is absolutely amazing and is so dedicated to helping her students. I've never had a professor who spent that much time outside of the class working with students. She cares so much and puts in a lot of effort to make sure that everyone who needs help gets it. However, the weakness would be the amount of time you need to invest into the class. Problem sets take forever and the material is very difficult, as you'd expect.

This was an excellent course. Some of the main strengths were that the professor explained a complex approach first to show students where the equations and concepts come from and then gave a more simplified direct approach. Also, the professor was extremely dedicated and was always there to help her students holding office hours daily.
The problem sets are extremely difficult, and impossible almost if you don't collaborate with peers and go to office hours and study halls. But, the examinations are fair.

The course was very difficult with problem sets taking about 15 hours a week. Moreover, the exams themselves were very challenging. However, Professor Steinacker provided a ton of guidance with study halls and office hours, and allowed to a large percentage of the grade to be composed of homework and participation which was a large stress relief.
Immense amount of support available. So much that several of the office hours overlapped with their schedules - perhaps schedule some in the morning right before class?

The course is graded very generously if you are willing to put in the work on the PSETs. Professor Steinacker is wonderful and although her PSETs can be very annoying and tedious at times, she is willing to help you through the entire thing.
I think the problem sets were excellent - they really supported learning - and the lectures were very engaging. I think this course was very well structured.

Overall the course was good and covered important aspects of introductory physics. The tests were well constructed, and aspects of the course including the lecture notes, the homework notes and the preparatory material for tests were very useful. The homeworks were, however, often a bit too long and complex and ended up being very time- consuming. Other than that, the course was fine.

The greatest strength is the teaching. Everything is explained clearly and thoroughly, and there are numerous resources available if help is desired. The problem sets were also challenging, which made for good practice for exams.

Strengths: Professor is very dedicated, class materials are organized and readily available, many sources of help (tutors, office hours, study halls)

Weaknesses: Lecture can move very quickly and can sometimes feel like blazing through types of calculations, homework is unwieldy and very time consuming
PSET's sometimes took far too long. Test taking areas should have stations for left-handed people.

I loved pretty much everything about this course. The study halls are so important to me, and the lecture notes help so much. The only thing that can be improved is the pace of the class; I often got lost because we went to fast; however, I understand that is the nature of the course.

Strengths: support of teacher, TA with study hall and office hours

Weakness: very challenging problem sets that made it impossible to work on problems by yourself
While the problem sets for this course were a lot of work, I felt that I learned a lot and will be apply this knowledge to other things.
Very interesting topic and enjoyed the demonstrations.
Professor Steinacker does an amazing job of presenting the information in a clear, straightforward, and approachable way. I think the homework assignments could do to be a fair amount shorter though.

I think Professor Steinacker was a very dedicated professor who really cared how her students were doing. I think physics is a very difficult subject to teach to students with a wide range of background in it, but I think she taught it very well.

I don't think there were any problems with the course itself, except that the exams and problem sets could be quite difficult. I suppose that this I s a good way to learn, and it was pretty well compensated for by the grading scheme. The material was clear and well organized, and Professor Steinacker was helpful and enthusiastic. Unfortunately, many students, like myself, took this class as a prerequisite, and were not particularly enthusiastic about physics. I think one way to draw in such students could be to offer more examples of real-world applications.
The problem sets created by the professor were virtually impossible for a student to try to do on their own.
The only weakness I can think of was that there were sometimes inconsistencies in grading, especially on the weekly psets.

The strength of this course is that Prof Steinacker is a really helpful and engaging lecturer. She's also a superwoman during office hours. I'm honestly not sure how she manages to help so many students in a few hours.

The weakness of this course is that it relies heavily on math to explain physics concepts. For instance, we would often derive equations we had never seen before, and then learn what they represented in the physical world. For me, this made the derivations extremely hard to follow because I had no idea what direction the equations were going.

The class is currently structured as: learn a basic equation, work through a derivation to a new equation, explain what that equation does and how it relates to physics.

I think this class would be greatly improved if class was structured as: Here's a physical concept (like simple harmonic motion) which has these properties, here's the SHM equation, you'll notice it also has these properties. Here's the derivation a famous physicist used to get to this point.

One last suggestion is to cut down the breadth of P-sets. Some questions were very tangential to what we learned in class and had little to do with what we were eventually tested on. I understand the desire to broaden our knowledge, but it's cruel to add broad questions onto P-sets that already take 10+ hours a week to finish. These p-sets honestly took me longer than all the homework for my other classes combined.

There was also a general feeling among the people I spoke to that their should never be problems that you can't solve with learning a specific math trick during office hours. There was one problem on the P set where you just had to divine a simplification by multiplying something by sin/cos in the maximum case and cos/sin in the minimum case, with absolutely no explanation, and pretty much no way to discover that on your own (unless you're extremely talented at math).

This class made me love physics and gave me the confidence that I could solve physics problems by following a systematic way of understanding and thinking. Professor Steinacker really helped me develop interest, confidence, intuition, and problem-solving ability through her in-class derivations, demonstrations, and style of lecturing. I loved the problem sessions and frequent office hours/peer tutoring hours. They really gave me the chance to ask questions and understand the material. 

My one suggestion for improvement is that the chapter on harmonic oscillators and waves be taught more slowly. I feel like we rushed through the material at the end.

One of the major strengths of this course is how much Adriane encourages working together on the psets. From her office hours to the many hours of study hall, it was very easy to find (the much needed) help for the psets.

This course is designed towards preparing engineers and physics majors and is much more difficult than necessary for pre-med students and students who have never taken physics before, particularly since it is an introductory physics class. The greatest strength of this class is the professor, who is very caring and wants to see her students succeed.

There is a lot of work involved in this class.  It takes up the majority of my study time during the week.  It is very difficult to complete problem sets if you do not seek guidance outside of class, but the good thing is that there is a lot of help available.  There is study hall with TAs every night and Adriane has office hours often, in addition to peer tutors.

The lectures were fast and confusing sometimes. Office hours and Study Halls are extremely helpful and available. Professor Steinacker is amazing. Review sessions were very helpful. Test review material in general was really helpful.

If you're premed/need to take a physics course, I would definitely recommend 180. It is a lot of work, but you will learn a ton and will understand the concepts at a fundamental level. Steinacker was a great professor, and she's the main reason why I chose to take this class over 170.

Yes. Professor Steinacker is no doubt the best professor I've ever had. She cares about all her students so much and gets to know all of them. Even if physics isn't your thing you'll do well with her.
If you have to take this class, then take it. If not, don't.

This is likely a required course if you're taking it - if you choose this class, be aware that if you don't already have a truly solid physics background, you will need to put in many hours of work to succeed. Problem sets are a significant part of your grade, and I would advise you go to office hours to do them (she does so the first day). However, if you cannot make the time to go to office hours 2-4 days a week and spend 6-10 hours outside of class there, this will be an incredibly challenging course. Exams aren't terrible - use the opportunity to do corrections wisely as this is a fantastic help. Adriane cares a lot about physics and wants her students to be as excited about it as she is. Lectures can be dense and occasionally nearly impossible to absorb, but her notes she posts are helpful and wonderful. It's just a matter of caring and using your resources. 

TLDR: Lots of effort, lots of time, great instructor, success takes actual work but is definitely achievable.

I would recommend this course to students who have to take it for their major. For students who don't have to take the course, it is a little bit too challenging and math intensive, I would probably not recommend it.
Yes. physics is always useful and you can't really go wrong with Professor Steinacker. I would recommend the course because the professor is truly amazing and makes learning physics bearable.

Highly recommend over 170. Steinacker is amazing and I'm in love with her. She is the best STEM professor I've ever had. Take it just for her. You will do well because she cares (and has office hours/study hall literally anytime/all the time).

I had doubts about my own ability to excel in this class, but Professor Steinacker made the material accessible. It will be your biggest workload for the term, but if you put in the time, you'll feel intellectually rewarded and your grade will be pretty good, too.

Yes! Even if you've studied physics extensively before, this is still a great class that is also great for your GPA. Each exam is curved AND there are test corrections, so it's rather easy to do well.
Only take this class is it is required. It sucks and takes a lot of time, but the grading isn't terrible, you just want to give up every week when you do the pset.

Physics is phun. In all honesty, it is the most difficult, time consuming course I've taken at Yale, but is well worth it. And let's be real here: if you're taking physics, it is probably because you have to, anyway.
I would absolutely recommend this course. Professor Steinacker is amazing and it was a privilege to attend her lectures.

I would totally recommend this class. If you want a realistic and thorough background in physics, this is the way to do it. Im pre-med so am taking this class for the MCAT and really feel like I am confident in my ability to answer any question that is thrown at me. Super challenging, super rewarding.

I'm sure most people taking this class need it for Engineering/Premed/Physics/etc., but I would definitely recommend taking this class if you are interested in physics at all. Adrienne truly cares about physics and will always show up to class with a smile on her face. She will answer questions if you have any, and there are TONS of resources to get help too. Office hours 4 days a week, study hall almost every weeknight, and TAs/Peer Tutors who will hold their own tutoring sessions. Physics is hard, but this class is doable if you put the time into it.
A great course and instructor for anyone trying to get their Physics requirements out of the way. Would recommend

PHYS 180 with Steinaker is a really strong class. While every exam will leave you doubting you know anything about physics, Steinaker truly pushes you to think analytically and understand the physical concepts behind the material.

If you're choosing between this and Physics 170, I think you should take this course (if you have any interest in physics whatsoever). I think it's worthwhile to take an interesting physics course where you learn about multiple applications of the subject, with students from many different majors and interest areas. Prof. Steinacker's lectures can be a bit confusing, but she posts really detailed lecture notes that you can learn from and goes out of her way to help students.
I'd recommend it if you need it, and if you're up for a challenge and want to learn physics I would also recommend it but it's a lot of time and kind of what you'd expect from physics.
Don't take this class if you hate work; there is a lot of it! However, if you do choose to take this class, you will find it to be a rewarding experience.

I would recommend Physics 180 for its collaborative nature and the organization of lecture material, and especially for Professor Steinacker, who is both an engaging lecturer and a supportive, helpful, approachable resource outside of class. For students with limited or no physics background, though, the pace might be prohibitive, and the material very difficult (but not impossible).
If they are interested in the STEM fields then yes
I would recommend this course to another student as long as they are willing to deal with the time consuming p-sets.
If you need physics, definitely opt for 180 over 170. The workload is huge, but it's incredibly well-taught and grades weren't a concern.
Take this class for Steinacker she is amazing!
If you're shopping this class you probably have to take it. Probably would not recommend for someone just looking for a Sc credit -- there are way more interesting classes out there.
If you're unsure about taking Physics 170 or 180, I'd recommend 180 just because Professor Steinacker is amazing and worth it! Even if you don't love/end up loving physics, you'll love her.

You probably have to take this course as a prerequisite, or as a pre-med, but even if you aren't required to take it, it's actually pretty great! I would recommend it just for Steinacker's incredible enthusiasm for physics, which is contagious. If you don't have a really strong physics background please please please be prepared to budget some serious time to completing the psets and attending study halls and office hours, but otherwise the workload is manageable and the exams are all pretty reasonable. Don't attempt the psets alone. You will cry. Find a study group or go to office hours or study hall instead, it will make your life much less miserable!

I would highly recommend this to anyone because it just makes you think about the world and life in a different world. We can explain everything in simple, elegant, beautiful, mathematical terms and it is so fascinating to learn how the math and science gives us insight to our world and other fields of science.
The psets are hard, but do go to office hours. I think going to office hours is required for this class.
Absolutely take this course with Professor Steinacker! She makes the material wondrous and exciting!

Yes if you are interested in physics! Definitely take it with Professor Steinacker--she is amazing. Exams were fair and you get half points back from test corrections. Psets took long but there are plenty of resources like office hours and study hall almost everyday.

I would recommend this class to another student. I think it would be a bit challenging if you hadn't taken physics before, but I think it is well taught and that resources/help are easily accessible if you need them.

Yeah! I mean just no it takes a lot of time the psets are 5-6 hours every week. But otherwise no downsides to taking this. Steinacker is awesome, grading is fair, class is fun. You absolutely must do psets with other people though. One option is to go to the study hall that is hosted literally every night (wild, I know), but heads up it can be overwhelming. Good luck.
If someone is planning on going into engineering I think that physics 180 is a great class to take in order to gain an understanding for the basics of physics.
Yes , I would. Because of all the stated reasons above
I would only recommend this class to people who have to take it for their major or for pre-med.

Definitely take this course if you have to. Professor Steinacker is wonderful and she really cares about all the students. The PSETs are challenging and take about 7-8 hours per week. In addition, it is difficult to do them on your own, so you will naturally develop study groups.

If a student has to take an introductory physics course, I would recommend this course. No matter what physics sequence they take, it will be challenging, but this course is well organized and is rewarding in the end.

adriane is the most helpful and patient professor i have ever had, and i would recommend this course because i learned a huge amount and at times enjoyed it. having said that, it is a huge amount of work; make sure you are free for office hours, you will have to go to them (esp if you are not a physics person)

I would highly recommend this course due to the easily accessible lecture materials and practice materials, highly accessible office hours and study halls, and wonderful teaching style of the professor.

Anybody who takes physics at Yale should be delighted to take it with Professor Steinacker. She is not only thoughtful and very involved with her teaching approach, but her passion clearly shines through and is quite contagious. Take it with Steinacker!!

I would highly recommend this course to another student, because it is structured in a way that allows the student to learn the content thoroughly, and yet be intellectually challenged in a way that doesn't feel impossible.

I found it challenging, for sure, but it was also rewarding. Get a good study group and meet weekly to work on the problem sets! One note: If you don't have a confident feeling when you're confronted with calculus (which I don't), you may find yourself struggling. Consider waiting until after you've taken a calculus course.
Sure, with the caveat that office hours and tutoring are more important than actually going to lecture. You'll learn much more in person.
yes, neccessary precursor to alot of stem majors
Only if it is a prerequisite for their major.
Yes, the class is awesome . Learning is the priority and help is always available.
I would highly recommend taking it with Prof. Steinacker. I needed to brush up on my calculus but that was fine too. Basic integral and derivatives are all you need.

Professor Steinacker is amazing and she is the #1 reason why you should take this course. It is challenging but it's worth it. You will be amazed at how much you learn in a semester. Study halls and office hours are tremendous resources; I definitely recommend going to them because they really do help.
I would definitely recommend this as an intro course because it is very possible to grow in this class as a scientist with the professor's help and the peer cooperation in place.

Yes, great intro to physics--I had never taken physics before at all, but Professor Steinacker is a wonderful professor an person-- highly recommend taking 180 over 170! Lecture notes are better organized than lecture itself, so you can follow along with the notes.  Also, PSets are impossible alone, but the TAs help a lot in office hours/study hall.

Physics is tough. Like really tougheven if you take AP Physics C. The problem sets are difficult and sometimes the exams are tough. But really Steinacker makes it so doable. I've never had a prof have office hours every day. In my 5 semesters as yale I've never had such a great professor. You must take it with Steinacker
Honestly wonderful and the professor was an angel. It made me excited about physics even though I have never felt that way about physics before in my life.
Absolutely. If you have to take physics, take 180 with Steinacker. It will change your perception of the subject completely.
Yes I absolutely recommend this course. Even if you are not a physics major, take this course! It teaches you to think critically and to problem solve and you really appreciate physics.
I would only reccomend the course to someone who needs it.

Would recommend, Professor Steinacker is really committed to getting her students to learn the material, and is very fair with how she grades them. Difficult workload because the psets that are assigned very week are difficult and often require going to office hours or seeing a peer tutor.

I would not recommend this course to another student unless it is a requirement or unless they have a real interest in physics. It is a very difficult course with a lot of work, but if you do take this class, definitely take it with Steinacker.
Prof Steinacker is really sweet and provides an immense amount of support. I'd recommend it.

I don't know too much about the other intro physics courses offered like 170, but I thoroughly enjoyed 180 because I felt like I learned a ton without it being overbearing and without getting your grade crushed. Just have to put in the time.
Yes - this is a great introduction to Physics that is well taught and well organized.
Yes, this is a well structured introductory physics course.

Absolutely! While the course is challenging, Prof. Steinacker does a great job of explaining concepts and truly cares about her students. She expects a lot of us, but she is also very kind and considerate.
This course is well-taught and straightforward. The PSETs can be difficult at times, but they provide great practice.

If you are willing to put in a lot of time and effort, this is a great class and will give you a solid foundation in physics. It is challenging and systematic. Professor Steinacker is an incredibly passionate teacher, but she expects the best from you. Many many hours are needed to do well.
Yes I would, as it is a necessary pre-req for many science classes.
Absolutely. This was a very interesting course that I was very satisfied with.
Enjoyable  course.

This physics class is very well-taught and about as interesting as physics can be on an introductory level. If you're pre-med, take this over 170. You will come out with a solid understanding of basic principles that will help you understand more complicated systems later on. From what I've heard, 170 tries to jump right into difficult applications without providing the same foundation that Prof. Steinacker emphasizes in this course.
Yes, this course does a great job of covering necessary intro physics concepts.
I think people should take this class if it is required or if they truly love physics, but not if they need a filler class.

If you have to take this course as a prerequisite, Professor Steinacker is a good teacher to take it with. She explained the material clearly and offered a lot of support, and though her assignments and exams were difficult, the grading scheme evens things out a bit. I didn't enjoy the class, but I don't like physics.
Yes, take this!
No, especially not if they had not taken a physics before this one.

It's intro. physics. You'll likely have to take it at some point. I would recommend taking 180 over some of the other courses, simply because it has the most dedicated professor, TAs, and peer tutors.

It's a standard physics class. the concepts will be very easy for you if you've taken AP physics C. Prof. Steinacker is awesome. Be aware that P-sets are literally impossible to do on your own and will take a minimum of 10 hours a week to finish. Office hours are basically mandatory because their are math tricks required to solve the problems that aren't covered in class and would be extremely difficult to figure out on your own.

I would definitely recommend this course to a student interested in physics and willing to work. Whereas I have sometimes felt that physics is one of those subjects where the work I put in all goes into a black hole and doesn't correlate at all with my performance, in this class I definitely gained confidence and felt that the amount of work I put in directly correlated with how well I could do. This class is very empowering that way. The class is very rigorous but you emerge with a gut-level understanding of the concepts and problem-solving. You also become convinced that physics is beautiful and interesting.
I would only recommend this class to students with a strong physics background.
I would not take this class unless I had to.  Unfortunately, it is one of the courses needed to fulfill many prerequisites.  It is very difficult and not very enjoyable if you don't like physics.
I would recommend this course because I learned a lot very deeply. I was able to collaborate with other students and that made the psets more enjoyable. It was challenging but good.
Physics 180 was a great class.
